title: What's up, Switzerland?: Challenges of a Large, Multilingual CMC Corpus

author: Simone Ueberwasser, Zurich Center for Linguistics, University of Zurich

segmentation: Good morning everybody.
I'm going to talk about it corpus or other two corpora that are not in the list.
I'm definitely sorry.
I forgot to send email.
We created a WhatsApp corpus in Switzerland, but I cannot really start off with WhatsApp calls.
I have to start off with the project that we had before, which was an SMS collection.
Then I'm going to introduce the corpus and then I'll show you what we've been doing to it in the last year.
We started our project.
I was here projects in 2009 by collecting bids less than 20, thirty thousand SMS, half a million tokens, so very small multilingual.
We have all national languages plus others in there and we did everything manually.
We had lots of student assistants who annotated languages they helped anonymized in normalized they did everything.
The only thing we did well it was more than that, but the only thing visible we did was the part of speech tagging based on the.
Student assistance normalization.
Now this is going to be important for what I really want to talk about WhatsApp because there we do not have the means to do things.
Manually.
We in 2014 we collected.
617 chats that's not quite true.
We had a bit more, but those are the ones that we can actually use.
These are seven other messages, 5 million tokens, so it's much larger.
It's much more difficult to work with, but again, it's multilingual corpus.
One word on terminology.
So do we talk about the same thing when two or more people are talking together, we call that a chat.
The one bubble that I write at one time is a message just so you understand my terminology.
We're running a project 1.5 million euros, which is quite a lot for linguistics in Switzerland.
Our leader is sort of a stock French professor.
We get 6 postdocs.
We got about five universities and project runs over three years.
So as you can see, we're shooting on a moving target.
Here I was students near doctoral students need data that we're working on.
For that reason, we are a bit chaotic.
We start here.
We do something to get the data to one student.
Then we start there to do something to get it to the other students.
It's a challenge.
Now what have we been doing to the?
So far we anonymize the data, we were lucky there to have our data from the SMS corpus.
We have lots and lots of names in the SMS corpus.
Every anonymized and we just took that data out and carried on within our organization.
Babe, it's cheeky there because we do not replace names by.
There were a token to SIS first name or something.
Instead you rotate our names.
That is 1 big advantage.
Our users know that those are fake names, so if they meet a real name they will not realize it's real name.
That helps us get anonymization, even if it's not perfect.
One problem we have a functional words in one language to their names in another language.
Things like that.
When a is chatting with B and a sense in a chat, we do not have base bees permission to use their data.
So what we did is we use the data where we have the permissions.

Quite often we have permission from more than one person, but if you have permission for only one person, we just disguise those messages by saying redacted Q that stands for us to search for it and then how many tokens?
How many characters.
That makes it easy for us to still see.
Oh, there were three messages here.
Before somebody else answered, but we cannot see what those measures messages were.
We have a problem because one doctoral student or postdoc is working on emojis and if we have emojis like that in the corpus, she cannot search for them.
There's no way to find everything that our faces or everything that is kept.
So instead we transferred those emojis to characters.
Again, we have the emoji Q and then a description.
The official description offers emojis, so our doctoral student can search for.
All faces or cats, whatever.
All that is ready.
To be used.
Now let's have a look at a few of the problems we have with our corpus.
You all know line one.
That's just the problems we have with CMC data.
It's noisy.
I had the same word in my preparation, but we have additional problems because we have different languages.
Meaning we have chats that are primarily in French.
We have.
Chats are primarily in German.
We have jets that are primarily in English and Spanish at the same time.
So we have the language problem, but within a message we also have a lot of code switching.
For some reason the Swiss like to code switch.
You show an example.
You see an example next slide and we have the Swiss German dialect which is just nothing.
There are no standards.
We cannot break rules for standard writing because we do not have them.
It's a language that is quite quite far apart from the standard.
So how do we deal with that?
And we have quite short units, so it's quite difficult to apply.
Natural language processing routines on that.
For example, for finding languages showing example from our SMS corpus, you can see that we get in one SMS.
We got Spanish, Italian, Spanish and Swiss, German and English now apply some natural language processing to that thing.
You won't find tools to cope with that.
And that's not unique.
We have quite a few of them.
Swiss German dialect Standard dialect standard German.
Just a few points we have.
We like to be loved occlusion eight.
We got this S which is normally written in acclimated, but in standard German it's an individual world.
We have words that have no equivalent in standard because we differentiate if we say dammit.
Differentiate because between direction and stationary forms, we have particles that we need that are not realized in Standard German.
So normalization is quite a task for us because our dialect is so far off standard germ.
To find out languages of those chats, we looked at 500 messages per chat and we define just languages that donate more than 100 messages.
So we have multilingual chats.
Now we have monolingual chats, but we have something that we call a main language.
And for one of the subprojects, one of my colleagues started looking at N grams to find out really on message or even token basis.
Whether it's Swiss German standard German.
French for doing quite well we use.
Processing tool that is available mold parse it and we really normalized and applied part of speech 92 percent 85%.
I think that's not bad.
We could improve on that because we have not manually normalized data.
We could train it, but we do not have the time.
As for the other languages, we have a student help us again and we are normalizing as much as we can pay for.
Um, and then we use the data at this data plus the data from the SMS corpus and from there we want to try to normalize to extend normalization to the whole corpus based on character elements.
Machine translation.
Success of no idea, and then we really going to tag it for German and for Italian Vermont.
We do not have the tools yet.
If anybody knows of a good tagger and tax set for Italian.
Very welcome.
May be important for you.
The estimate scope is already freely available.
What's up Corpus will be at the end of the project.
We do not want people to do linguistic research that threatens our doctoral students, so it's only at the moment.
It's only available upon request.
If we see that you're not threatening our work, you can have access.
That's it, thank you.
Am I doing?
